subject: [REPORT] I think I Downloaded Something Evil...
instructions:
An accountant in your organization reported that after attempting to download a productivity app on their workstation, their system began exhibiting unusual behavior, and they noticed a black console window briefly appearing throughout the day.

You have been assigned to investigate the extracted event logs from the compromised endpoint to determine the actions taken during the incident and to identify any indicators or artifacts associated with the compromise. You have access to both the Sysmon and Security event logs, which were recorded around the time of the incident.

Challenge Files:

  • C:\Users\tcm\Desktop\SOC_Level_1\Endpoint_Security\Windows\Challenge\security.evtx
  • C:\Users\tcm\Desktop\SOC_Level_1\Endpoint_Security\Windows\Challenge\sysmon.evtx

questions.question: What is the hostname of the computer that generated the logs files?
questions.hint: If you're using the Event Viewer, look for the Computer field.

questions.question: Based on the Sysmon Process Create logs, what is the name of the user account that was browsing the web using Microsoft Edge?
questions.hint: Within the Sysmon events, you can check the User field, which indicates the user whose context the msedge.exe process was running under.

questions.question: Look for events that may relate to files that were downloaded onto the system. What is the filename of the suspicious executable?
questions.hint: Within the Sysmon events, you can check Event Code 15, which is logged when a named file stream is created. Make sure you identify the primary file stream (containing the main content of the file) rather than an Alternate Data Stream (ADS).

questions.question: What is the SHA-256 hash value of the executable?
questions.hint: Within the Sysmon events, you can check Event Code 15, which is logged when a named file stream is created. Make sure you identify the primary file stream (containing the main content of the file) rather than an Alternate Data Stream (ADS).

questions.question: What is the popular threat label?
questions.hint: Look for a similar event to the one you identified in the previous question. This time, look for the creation of a Zone.Identifier data stream, which stores metadata about the file's origin.

questions.question: In defanged format, what is the full URL that was hosting the executable?
questions.hint: Look for a similar event to the one you identified in the previous question. This time, look for the creation of a Zone.Identifier data stream, which stores metadata about the file's origin.

questions.question: Filter for process create events related to the executable. What is the Process ID (PID) of the malware's first execution?
questions.hint: Process Create events in Sysmon have the Event ID of 1.

questions.question: Based on the previously identified Process ID (PID), find any subsequent network connection events. What is the IP address and port number that the malware connected back to? Answer format: IP:Port.
questions.hint: Network Connection events in Sysmon have the Event ID of 3. You can also use the Find... feature within Event Viewer.

questions.question: The malware then spawned a child cmd.exe process to give the attacker remote access onto the system. What is the Process ID (PID) of this cmd.exe process?
questions.hint: Process Create events in Sysmon have the Event ID of 1.

questions.question: Use the Security event log to identify any user account created events. What is the name of the likely backdoor account that the attacker created?
questions.hint: User account creation events have the Event ID of 4720. Look for the Account Name field under the New Account section.

questions.question: After establishing a foothold on the system, the attacker focused on credential access. In defanged format, what is the full URL of the domain account abuse tool that the attacker downloaded onto the system?
questions.hint: Back in the Sysmon logs, look for any FileCreate (ID 11) events for any interesting files being created by the attacker. From here, trace back the Process ID (PID) to the original process.

questions.question: What native command-line tool did the attacker use to establish persistence on the compromised system?
questions.hint: You can use the Find... feature within Event Viewer to enumerate any child processes with the Parent Process ID (PID) of the cmd.exe process identified earlier. Use the keyword "ParentProcessId: 5392".

questions.question: What is the IP address and port number that the implanted persistence mechanism connects back to to download and execute? Answer format: IP:Port.
questions.hint: You can use the Find... feature within Event Viewer to enumerate any child processes with the Parent Process ID (PID) of the cmd.exe process identified earlier. Use the keyword "ParentProcessId: 5392".
